entry.title: Avery Lynch Strikes Again with Poignant New Single “the boys who don’t know what they want”
entry.summary: Avery Lynch unveils her latest emotional masterpiece, “the boys who don’t know what they want,” out today via RECORDS. Known…
entry.content:
Avery Lynch unveils her latest emotional masterpiece, “the boys who don’t know what they want,” out today via RECORDS. Known for her soul-stirring, piano-driven ballads, Avery has amassed over 100 million streams, cementing her place as a voice of raw, relatable storytelling.

With its minimalist production and hauntingly beautiful vocals, “the boys who don’t know what they want” captures the frustration and vulnerability of navigating almost-relationships—those confusing connections where words and actions never quite align. “The title says it all,” Avery explains. “I wrote this about those situations where someone acts like they want a relationship but won’t commit—or the ones who want it but won’t act on it. It’s not necessarily sad, just a reality we’ve all seen and don’t want to keep experiencing.”

A sister-song to her fan-favorite track “you’re just a guy,” this latest release reinforces Avery’s ability to turn life’s everyday heartaches into poetic reflections, striking a chord with listeners who have been in the same emotional limbo.

Originally from Pennsylvania, Avery began composing music at just seven years old, with the piano as her storytelling companion. Now based in Los Angeles, her signature sound—delicate yet deeply expressive—remains at the heart of her artistry. Every song starts with Avery at her piano, crafting heartfelt demos that evolve into the lush, melancholic soundscapes fans have come to love.

Described as a “happy girl filled with sad songs,” Avery weaves personal experiences, pop culture, and emotional nuance into every lyric. With acclaim from outlets like Just Jared and EARMILK and a growing army of devoted listeners, her recent signing with RECORDS (Sony Music) marks a new era—one that promises even greater heights for this rising star.

entry.title: Maddie Regent Unveils the Hauntingly Beautiful “Turtleneck” Ahead of Debut Album
entry.summary: New York City-based indie-pop artist Maddie Regent continues to captivate with her latest single, “Turtleneck”, a mesmerizing preview of her…
entry.content:
New York City-based indie-pop artist Maddie Regent continues to captivate with her latest single, “Turtleneck”, a mesmerizing preview of her upcoming debut album, On the phone with my mom, set for release on May 16th.

Building on the magnetic vulnerability of past singles like The Wolf, You Could Break My Heart, and Sleeptalking, “Turtleneck” immerses listeners in Maddie’s signature dreamy indie-pop world. Guided by her crystalline vocals, the track weaves a delicate tapestry of shimmering melodies and introspective lyricism, effortlessly blending whimsy with raw emotional depth.

At its heart, “Turtleneck” explores the disorienting aftermath of a breakup, where the past feels safer than the present. “It’s about how lost you can feel after leaving a relationship,” Maddie shares. “There’s a temptation to anchor yourself in memories rather than face reality.” The song’s ethereal yet melancholic soundscape perfectly embodies this push and pull, capturing the emotional limbo between heartbreak and hope.

Originally from Toronto and now based in New York City, Maddie discovered songwriting at just 12 years old, using music as an emotional outlet to navigate her anxieties. Since her debut in 2021, she has released two critically praised EPs, MISS REGENT and Girl of Your Dreams, earning recognition from tastemakers like Atwood Magazine and EARMILK.

With longtime collaborator Cade Hoppe—her partner in both music and life—Maddie has carefully crafted a sound that fuses catchy pop hooks with deeply personal storytelling. Now, with On the phone with my mom, her most ambitious project to date, Maddie Regent is poised for a breakthrough year in 2025.

entry.title: Sunsetto Unveils His Debut Album: The Sun, The Moon & The Big Machine
entry.summary: Toronto’s rising alt-pop sensation sunsetto has arrived with his highly anticipated debut album, The Sun, The Moon & The Big…
entry.content:
Toronto’s rising alt-pop sensation sunsetto has arrived with his highly anticipated debut album, The Sun, The Moon & The Big Machine. This bold and evocative project fuses introspective lyricism with expansive production, drawing listeners into a cinematic exploration of love, ambition, and the complexities of the digital era.

Far more than just a collection of tracks, the album weaves a conceptual narrative around three powerful forces—warmth, passion, and the pursuit of seemingly unattainable dreams. “I wanted to tell a story through my experiences, balancing the push and pull of chasing ambitions while still yearning for something real,” sunsetto explains. “In a world where we consume so much daily, it’s easy to overlook the beauty in the present moment. This album is my attempt to capture those fleeting, often neglected emotions.”

Recorded between Los Angeles and Toronto over the past year, sunsetto’s journey to this milestone has been met with growing acclaim. His recent singles have resonated deeply with a new generation of pop fans, his poignant storytelling and genre-blurring sound marking him as an artist to watch.

Among the standout tracks is CROSSFIRE, a poignant anthem co-written and produced by 9AM (Leon Bridges, Noah Cyrus). With haunting melodies and raw lyricism, the song encapsulates sunsetto’s signature style. “It’s about lost potential and the choices that define us,” he shares. “That feeling of being caught between dreams and reality is something I’ve lived, and I wanted to bring that honesty into my music.”

Blending emotional depth with sonic innovation, sunsetto is carving a distinct lane in the alt-pop space. With The Sun, The Moon & The Big Machine, he invites listeners on an intimate journey through his world—one where every lyric, beat, and melody tells a story of passion, struggle, and self-discovery.

Stream The Sun, The Moon & The Big Machine now:
https://sunsetto.lnk.to/SMBM

Meet sunsetto: The Genre-Defying Artist Behind the Music

Few artists capture the spirit of their generation like Toronto-based singer, songwriter, and producer sunsetto (Kyle Mischiek). Raised on Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia, he split his time between music and skateboarding, forging a creative path that would shape his sound. Initially dabbling in rap and beat-making during high school, he refined his craft at prestigious songwriting camps led by GRAMMY® and JUNO Award-winning songwriter Gordie Sampson (Carrie Underwood, Keith Urban).

His breakout moment came in 2020 with the viral success of his debut single don’t leave, amassing hundreds of thousands of streams and catching the attention of tastemakers like EARMILK and Fashionably Early. His distinctive fusion of dance, rap, R&B, and modern country—paired with lyrics that oscillate between euphoria and deep introspection—has solidified his place in the alt-pop landscape.

This year’s string of releases, including PLANS, POTENTIAL, GREEN TEXTS, DON’T LEAVE ME BEHIND (feat. Sinéad Harnett), BIG MACHINE, and SHE’S THE WHOLE WORLD, showcases his evolving artistry and connection to a new wave of pop listeners. Now, with The Sun, The Moon & The Big Machine, sunsetto embarks on his most ambitious chapter yet—one that cements his status as a force to be reckoned with in modern music.

entry.title: VANARIN’s Mesmerizing New Release: A Taste of Their Upcoming Third Album
entry.summary: As anticipation builds for VANARIN’s highly awaited third album under the Dischi Sotterranei label, the British-Italian band continues to make…
entry.content:
As anticipation builds for VANARIN’s highly awaited third album under the Dischi Sotterranei label, the British-Italian band continues to make waves across the music world. Already earning accolades and securing their spot among the most compelling acts of the moment, VANARIN’s recent feature on the prestigious BBC platforms has solidified their rising-star status. Now, to ease the wait for their next big release, the band is gifting fans with a new single “What We Said”.


This latest track is a mesmerizing psych ballad, anchored by an entrancing piano progression that takes center stage. Layered atop is the frontman’s hypnotic voice, which weaves a spellbinding rhythm, undulating and intoxicating as it explores the haunting aftermath of a love lost. Like a mantra, the lyrics obsessively question the meaning behind a lover’s parting words, plunging the listener into a dreamy yet poignant introspection.



Fans of Tame Impala’s Currents will feel the familiar pull of melancholic yet circular lyrics, while those who appreciate The Beatles’ experimental era will be drawn to the artful manipulation and pitch-shifted vocal sections. But that’s not all—the track’s lush sonic landscape is further enriched by a warm, soulful bass line and vintage-inspired guitar phrases that seem to echo straight out of the 1960s.

What truly sets VANARIN apart is their meticulous attention to detail. Every element of “What We Said” unfolds with a fresh, unexpected twist, creating a soundscape that feels innovative yet timeless. It’s this masterful balance that makes their signature style unmistakable and keeps their audience coming back for more.

With such a tantalizing preview, VANARIN’s third album promises to be a standout moment in contemporary music—one that fans and critics alike will be eager to experience.

entry.title: Twinnie’s Bold New Era: The Country-Pop Starlet Unleashes “Hypothetically”
entry.summary: Twinnie has just released the bouncy music video to her latest single, "Hypothetically," which made its world premiere in an…
entry.content:
Twinnie has just released the bouncy music video to her latest single, "Hypothetically," which made its world premiere in an exclusive at Daily Mail. The music video stars the talented Twinnie in a striking leopard-print romper capture precisely the playfulness and fearlessness of the song. She's a commanding presence-think a world where this songstress is drawing in viewers "into her world of flirtatious fun," according to Daily Mail.

"Hypothetically" arrived September 20, 2024, and has already garnered rave reviews. As best put by Nashville Socialite, it's an "absolute knockout" of fresh country-pop peppered with a healthy dose of 90s girl-power nostalgia. Twinnie's carefree yet reflective lyrics meander through love, possibilities, and the unspoken "what-ifs," while channeling her trademark warmth and confidence-a mix of strengths and vulnerabilities not unlike those embodied by none other than Shania Twain herself. Meanwhile, Music City Melodies drew the parallel between it and Jessie James Decker by mentioning that Twinnie's flirtatious lyrics are a reflection of Decker's bold style-an inspiring quality urging everybody to be brazen.
like

This single marks a new turn for Twinnie, where she leaves her "sad-girl" phase for a more fun and confident sound. Co-written with Reid Sorel and Grace Gunn, "Hypothetically" teases themes from her forthcoming sophomore album, Something We Used To Say, due out on November 8, 2024.

Off the back of her new album, Twinnie has announced a small, intimate tour of the UK this November, stopping off in London, Brighton, Manchester, York and Glasgow. Her Manchester show has already sold out.


Last year, Twinnie joined the cast of Emmerdale to play Jade, the mean boxing promoter. On her latest role, Twinnie says: "Life has been crazy juggling acting and music, with lots of back and forth between Nashville and Yorkshire, but I'm loving every second of it!

No stranger to acting, Twinnie has a history on British television with roles in the shows Doctors and Hollyoaks, where she received much acclaim for her portrayal of Porsche McQueen, whose storyline tackled critical social issues like childhood sexual abuse.

Twinnie became the first British artist to sing the American National Anthem at the stadium of Nashville SC, GEODIS Park, stamping her credentials as a global star with an infectious dynamism.

Twinnie's life story has been very far from ordinary. At her tender age, she had acted among giants like Glenn Close and Robin Thicke while her West End performances in Chicago and Rock of Ages hinted at the shining star she was to become. Since the launch of her solo career in 2020, she consistently blew minds with her genre-defying sound and continues to inspire, recently performing at AmericanaFest's "Stella + Friends: The Power of Women in Music."

Hypothetically" is only the beginning of her exciting new chapter.

entry.title: CHIEF STATE Releasing 5-song acoustic EP on April 5
entry.summary: Vancouver, BC pop punk trailblazers, Chief State, unveil their latest release - a 5-song acoustic EP that promises to redefine your…
entry.content:
Vancouver, BC pop punk trailblazers, Chief State, unveil their latest release - a 5-song acoustic EP that promises to redefine your connection with their music. Set to release via Mutant League Records in April 2024, "The Acoustic EP" invites listeners to rediscover Chief State's catalog through a captivating and intimate lens.

The first single "Living Out A Lie" will be released on February 21.

Pre-save 'The Acoustic EP' here: https://orcd.co/chiefstate

Of the EP's first single and video, "Living Out A Lie", front man Fraser Simpson says, "As the name suggests, this song is about the feeling of your life being a lie, self-doubt, faking it until you make it, imposter syndrome. Something I constantly struggle with. I’ve made a lot of choices to get where I am today and often I’m not sure if I’m actually being true to myself. The song also speaks directly about doubt in previous relationships, whether my heart was actually in it. The video, created by the brilliant Lindsey Blane, really tied this idea together and we deliberately ended it before knowing the answer to the guy’s proposal. I think we’re all a little glossy on the surface, we show what we want to show but once it comes down to a life changing choice, like shown in the video, the truth will come out."

In honor of Valentine's Day, Chief State and Mutant League Records have launched a limited edition "Valentines Day" shirt design, available exclusively through the Mutant League webstore.

All V-day shirt purchases through April 5th will receive a handwritten lyric by Fraser Simpson of Chief State, along with a song from the upcoming EP.

entry.title: The Conquest of Madness: Aguirre and the Perils of Power
entry.summary: Werner Herzog, director of Aguirre, the Wrath of God, sought a location atop a mountain near Machu Picchu in Peru…
entry.content:
Werner Herzog, director of Aguirre, the Wrath of God, sought a location atop a mountain near Machu Picchu in Peru to shoot the opening scenes. He led his cast and crew of 450 people, together with a procession of horses, pigs, and llamas, up the mountainside. His group slogged down an ancient stairway carved into the rocks by the Incans centuries ago, traveling through dense jungle on steep footing made slick by rain. Clouds blanketed the entire mountain, shrouding everything in dense, moist fog, allowing no visibility. Even the local upland tribes got vertigo-stricken at 14,000 feet, but the players withstood the conditions in their heavy costume armor and Spanish conquistador clothing.

The journey appeared impossible. Herzog had to persuade his crew to keep going, to keep ascending higher and higher along a vertical drop of almost 2,000 feet. Herzog was concerned that their efforts had been in vain when they arrived at their destination. The clouds eventually cleared, and daylight broke through. Herzog got his shots, capturing a line of actors, barely specks in the frame, descending down the Incan stairway between a severe mountain slope and a cloud of fog. Herzog believed a miracle had occurred. He reflected on his good fortune, saying, "It was on this day that I definitely came to know my destiny." Ironically, it was that kind of mad determination and assumption of fate that pushed his film's zealous protagonist, Lope de Aguirre.

Before he was recognized for filming documentaries like Grizzly Man (2005) and Encounters at the End of the World (2008) about people consumed by passion in remote, unattainable locales, Herzog made narrative films about the same subject, demonstrating that he shared their obsession. Aguirre, the Wrath of God was Herzog's first such picture, as well as his first international hit outside of his own West Germany. His 1972 film depicts a failed Spanish voyage to find El Dorado, the legendary Incan city of gold.

A fever dream

On the surface, the film looks to be a traditional period adventure about the fight between humans and nature, with Spanish conquistadors venturing into the unknown to collect treasure, only to be defeated by the unconquered forest. However, upon closer observation, the entire picture is set in a fever dream of obsessive urges. After all, what better example of crazy than conquistadors marching off in a specified direction with hundreds of troops and resources in tow, hoping to discover a place whose location is unknown and, ultimately, does not exist? Many of Herzog's greatest films feature rebels against both humanity and nature.

They strive for an unachievable goal, possibly out of pride or vanity, but they are eventually swallowed and regurgitated by Nature. Herzog knew these obsessions better than most; he later experienced them when filming Fitzcarraldo (1982), as well as countless other tales and documentaries, including Aguirre, the Wrath of God. He exhibits his own obsession by directing this ambitious film to follow his subject into the heart of darkness, rather than filming on a studio lot or a safer place.

Detachment from reality 

Herzog never meant to make Aguirre, the Wrath of God into a historical account of Lope de Aguirre's life and times. In reality, his initial concept for the picture was inspired by a children's book that included a brief segment on Aguirre. What captivated the director the most was the figure's complete craziness. When Aguirre joined Don Pedro de Ursúa's expedition to find El Dorado, he already had a reputation for being a vicious and ruthless conquistador. On the trip, Aguirre overcame his superiors and took command. In a manic letter discovered during Herzog's research, Aguirre denounces King Felipe II of Spain, declaring him "dethroned and stripped of all rights," and renaming himself "the Wrath of God."

He went on to declare himself "the new Emperor of El Dorado and New Spain" and led his captured expedition into the unknown. Finally, he arrived at the Atlantic, no closer to discovering El Dorado, and all but a few of his followers had died. This daring, this detachment from reality while immersed in nature, drew the director in, and Herzog determined to recreate it in his film. "Aguirre is one of history's great losers," the filmmaker once stated in an interview, and the concept of Aguirre's unusually fixated worldview layered his screenplay more than actual reality. "The entire script is pure invention," Herzog revealed in an interview. What he meant to represent was not facts and dates, but the frame of mind attributed to Aguirre, the type of adventurer who seeks a wealth of riches while also pursuing his own death.

entry.title: Bolaji Badejo: The Actor Behind the Xenomorph
entry.summary: With a height of 208 cm (6'10"), Bolaji Badejo embodied the Alien in "Alien." He became the stereotypical monster, dressed…
entry.content:
With a height of 208 cm (6'10"), Bolaji Badejo embodied the Alien in "Alien." He became the stereotypical monster, dressed in an outfit that included elongated limbs and a skeletal, biomechanical appearance.


Using skillful cinematography to enhance the Alien's unsettling aura through camera angles, lighting, and framing, the special effects crew amplified this effect.


Following his move to Nigeria in 1980, Badejo turned down roles in the "Alien" sequels, which resulted in a greater use of puppetry and animation in these movies. That movie "Alien" is still his only credit.

He established an art gallery in Nigeria in 1983 before he unfortunately died at the age of 39 from sickle cell illness in 1992.

entry.title: San Diego's Strike Twelve Release 'Last Band Standing’
entry.summary: San Diego/Temecula punks Strike Twelve have released the new album 'Last Band Standing' via Thousand Islands Records. Watch the video…
entry.content:
San Diego/Temecula punks Strike Twelve have released the new album 'Last Band Standing' via Thousand Islands Records.

Watch the video for "Baseball Bat" here: https://youtu.be/NmmM301ezr4.

Video shot by Danny, Joey, Matty, and Melisa. Edited by Aaron Bruski.

Guitarist/vocalist Matty T says, "'Baseball Bat' involves a violent physical release caused by prolonged emotional suppression. Sometimes I just can’t bite my tongue any longer and before I open my big mouth it’s better to physically exert myself."

Strike Twelve is

Matt Turek (“Matty T”) - guitar / vocals

Joe Treister (“Joey T”) - bass / vocals

Dan Bahou (“Danny B”) - drums

Danny B, Matty T and Joey T of So-Cal punk rock band Strike Twelve have been playing live at your local dive since 2003. Whether they’re first or last in the lineup, they will undoubtedly be the band having the most fun. They love what they do and they love doing it with each other, which is why all three members have stuck with the band since the beginning. With an unmatched chemistry that can only be developed with twenty years of friendship, it’s safe to say that this isn’t just a phase. Their new album Last Band Standing will be out in summer 2023 on Montreal-based Thousand Islands Records, and hopefully it will help to take their excellent adventure to the international stage.
